1. Possession play: Teams often try to keep possession of the ball in order to control the tempo of the game and limit their opponent's scoring opportunities.

2. Counter-attacks: Teams often use fast and direct attacks to quickly move the ball up the field and score goals when their opponents are out of position.

3. High pressing: Some teams use a high-pressing strategy, in which they aggressively press and tackle their opponents high up the field to disrupt their attacks.

4. Wide play: Teams often use wingers to stretch the opposition's defenses by delivering crosses into the box for their strikers to finish.

5. Set-piece goals: Teams often work on set piece routines such as free-kicks and corners to create scoring opportunities.

These are just a few examples of tactics that are commonly used in professional football tournaments. However, each team may have their own unique approach based on their playing style and the strengths of their players.

Yes, long-ball tactics are also commonly used in football tournaments, especially when a team has a striker who is strong, fast, and good at holding up the ball. In this style of play, the team plays long balls up the field from their own half to the opponent's half, hoping for their striker to win the ball or flick it on to a teammate. This strategy is useful when the team is under pressure or wants to bypass the midfield and quickly move the ball up the field.

However, long-ball tactics can be risky, as the team can lose possession of the ball quickly if the striker fails to keep the ball or if the opposition's defenders intercept the ball. As such, it is important for teams that use this tactic to have a strong defense to handle counter-attacks from the opposition.

Yes, football coaches and analysts use tactical analysis to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of their own team and their opponents. Additionally, analysts may use statistical models and machine learning algorithms to predict the effectiveness of certain tactics against an opposing team. Overall, tactical analysis is an important part of modern football, and teams are using advanced analytics and technology to stay ahead of the competition.
